Sentence: At the party, Dixon meets Welch's son Bertrand and his (Dixon) girlfriend Christine, who have come up to the country from London
Dixon's friend Carol Goldsmith finally convinces Dixon to make a move for Christine by revealing that she (Christine) has been having an affair with Bertrand
Dixon rallies his (Dixon) courage and asks Christine, whom Bertrand has been ignoring, to let him (Dixon) take her (Christine) home early
Christine agrees and explains to Dixon in the taxi how Bertrand has been mistreating her (Christine)
On the day of Dixon's lecture, Bertrand comes to Dixon's room and accuses Dixon of seeing Christine behind his (Dixon) back
Bertrand tells Dixon that Dixon is wasting his (Dixon) time and Dixon, fed up with Bertrand's hypocrisy and condescending bossiness, gets in a fight with Bertrand
Bertrand gives Dixon a black eye and Dixon knocks him (Dixon) down
Christine tells Dixon that she (Christine) knows of Bertrand's affair with Carol and has broken off their relationship
